text:
The whole unfortunate ordeal starts out with a night hunt, as most unfortunate things in Wei Wuxian’s life regularly do.

He and Lan Wangji had been part of a small hunting party in response to some complaints near Caiyi Town of graves being ravaged and upturned. The whole situation was pretty unbecoming, with half-decaying limbs being dragged out of the ground here and there, and the locals were starting to complain about the smell, among other things. 

Wei Wuxian certainly isn’t in Gusu for his health, nor for any night hunts that the GusuLan sect could easily take care of themselves. No, he’d found himself in Gusu with Jiang Cheng and shijie, mostly against his will, for a conference at the Cloud Recesses later in the week, where sect leaders and some select disciples would discuss next steps in the wake of the Sunshot Campaign — and the power vacuum left by the QishanWen sect’s fall from grace. 

All fine, and good. Wei Wuxian isn’t exactly thrilled to be back in the Cloud Recesses, save for the liquor selection, but he far prefers it to Nightless City.

The corpse-disturber, or whatever it is, was surely nothing that a small group of cultivators couldn’t handle, which is why he, Lan Wangji, Jiang Cheng, and a few others had been deployed to solve the issue.

Unfortunately, the day’s hunting party included Jin Zixuan, who was steadily tempting Wei Wuxian into committing homicide.

After seeing the seventh snappy flip of hair over a bow and arrow, Wei Wuxian had decided he’d had quite enough of that, thank you, and had roped a reluctant Lan Wangji into splitting off from the rest of the group to follow a separate trail of tracks, leading south while the rest of the party headed west.

Which is how the two of them had ended up alone in a small, dank-smelling cave, currently struck dumb by an ear-splitting screech and an explosive flash of light.

It takes several moments for Wei Wuxian to come back to himself; he blinks hard, but the darkness of the cave doesn’t abate even a little bit, other than the searing white dots flickering in his vision. His ears are still ringing. 

The cave is silent now, aside from their own mingled breathing — the creature, whatever it is, had been effectively spooked off.

Fine, maybe this hadn’t been one of Wei Wuxian’s brighter ideas, as Lan Wangji had been so fond of reminding him every step of the way here. Not in words, of course, so much as judgy mannerisms and withering squinting. 

“Lan Zhan?” he asks, panting and groping around in the dark. He finds a wiry shoulder under his palm a moment later. “Lan Zhan.”

“Mn,” Lan Wangji replies, and something sounds — different about his voice. Off. Wei Wuxian doesn’t think much further on it.

“Are you okay? Ugh, it’s so dark that I can barely breathe. Here.” He sinks his teeth into his thumb, wincing at the sting as he draws blood, and traces a lighting talisman into the space in front of him.

A gout of orange light flares around them, illuminating Lan Wangji’s tired face before his and it’s — it’s — gray eyes gazing back at him, caught silver in the talisman’s glow, and Wei Wuxian has one stunned, uncomprehending moment to take in his own features gazing back at him before he shouts, and the light snuffs out.

“Wei Ying,” Lan Wangji’s voice — Wei Wuxian’s voice — rings out in the dark, and he sounds panicked in a way that Wei Wuxian can’t ever recall hearing from him. “My core, it’s — it’s —” He can’t finish his sentence, the words choking off, and Wei Wuxian feels every drop of blood in his body ice over.

“Oh,” he says, weakly, “about that,” and then conveniently passes out.

—

When Wei Wuxian comes to, it’s to the uneven stagger of footsteps beneath him, and he squirms. There’s a sharp huff of effort directly above him, and when he opens his eyes, bleary, he sees his own jawline above him, jutted in concentration. He’s being carried — with considerable strain, given the new size difference — and Wei Wuxian struggles harder as he grips his bearings. 

“Lan Zhan,” he says, “what are you — put me down.” 

Lan Wangji doesn’t answer him, just stubbornly keeps walking without looking down at him, and Wei Wuxian can’t tell if he’s unspeakably angry or just pigheaded.

“Please,” he adds. “Lan Zhan, what happened?”

Lan Wangji stops, then sets Wei Wuxian gently on his feet. The change in elevation makes all the blood rush to Wei Wuxian’s head, and he sits with a heavy thud on the ground.

Wei Wuxian looks around, trying to reorient himself. It seems they’re still some way from the entrance to Cloud Recesses, but still, Lan Wangji had carried him an impressive distance, given he’s bleeding from a head wound and shaking with fatigue.

Trembling, Wei Wuxian stares at his hands. The fingers are long, beautiful, moon-pale — nothing like his own worn, sun-browned hands. They carry the delicate elegance of a seasoned guqin player and the weathered strength of a practiced swordsman.

They’re Lan Wangji’s hands. Wei Wuxian would know them anywhere. This is Lan Wangji’s body.

Apparently seeing his own body before him hadn’t been sufficient for the reality of the situation to set in. Now, he’s beginning to fully panic.

“Lan Zhan,” he says in a strangled voice, patting down his chest (broader than his own), his arms (much stronger than his own), his waist—

“Stop that,” Lan Wangji says in a similar tone, and Wei Wuxian looks up at him; his fists are clenched, his lips pressed into a thin white line.

“What the hell happened?” Wei Wuxian asks, shriller than anything befitting Lan Wangji’s low voice.

“I don’t know,” Lan Wangji says tightly.

“How do we fix it?”

“I don’t know.” Lan Wangji closes his eyes, seeming as though he’s wading through some implacable emotion, before he says, “Wei Ying.”

“What?”

“Your golden core.” A slight tremor shakes the composure in Lan Wangji’s voice. He closes his eyes, as though pained. “It’s…”

“You can’t tell anyone,” Wei Wuxian says, and Lan Wangji’s eyes fly open. “You have to swear to me, Lan Zhan, that no one can know.”

“Know what?” Lan Wangji whispers. He's still shaking a little; carrying Wei Wuxian all that way must have really sapped his strength.

Wei Wuxian falls silent.

“Wei Ying,” Lan Wangji says, much harsher. 

“It’s gone,” Wei Wuxian says, and he feels a hard knot slide up his throat. He swallows around it with difficulty. “I gave it up.”

Lan Wangji takes a stumbling half-step back, like he’s been dealt an unexpected blow.

“Who did this,” he says then. His voice is clipped, quiet, dangerous. He’s definitely shaking now, more than before, his expression one Wei Wuxian has never seen. It’s murderous. His fists are clenched at his sides. He asks again through his teeth: “Who.” 

“It was my choice." Wei Wuxian is suddenly unable to look Lan Wangji in the eye. He knots his fingers in the grass, roping it around and around his knuckles until the circulation cuts off.

“Why,” Lan Wangji says, faintly. “How.”

“Because Jiang Cheng lost his,” Wei Wuxian says. “He’s sect leader now, and — and I had a perfectly healthy core. It wasn’t even a question.”

Lan Wangji makes this quiet noise like he’s been punched. 

Wei Wuxian swallows the unpleasant emotion welling up in him, fast and thick. “He can’t ever know,” he says. “Lan Zhan, please, I’m begging you — please keep it between us.”

“You…” Lan Wangji starts, and then is evidently unable to finish whatever he wants to say, because he cuts himself off, goes silent again. 

It’s too intense. Too serious. Too much. With all his effort, Wei Wuxian summons up a thin smile, dons his bravado like armor again. “Ah, Lan Zhan, it’s all fine, really. What did the son of a servant need with all that anyway? Much more fitting that Jiang Cheng has it.”

“Wei Ying,” Lan Wangji whispers.

“Enough, enough.” Wei Wuxian’s skin is starting to prickle; he can’t take Lan Wangji’s scolding if that’s what he’s going to do, not on this. Not about this. “Let’s not speak of it, okay? Let’s figure out what we’re going to do. I…I realize this predicament leaves you powerless now, huh? It’s okay, I can teach you some talismans on the most basic things. That way you can protect yourself, just until this situation sorts out.”

Lan Wangji is still faced away from him, his chin angled in the direction of Cloud Recesses, Wei Wuxian’s crimson hair ribbon flapping in the wind behind him. Is he angry? Wei Wuxian can’t tell. He’s probably angry — a golden core transfer is certainly not orthodox. 

“Thank you for carrying me out of there,” Wei Wuxian begins.

“Do not thank me,” Lan Wangji says at once. So, definitely angry then.

Wei Wuxian goes quiet again, uncertain of what to say in the uncomfortable silence that follows. He tries for levity. 

“Consider yourself blessed, Lan Zhan! You’re now much more handsome than you were before,” he says with a forced laugh, and makes a face when he’s stonewalled with Lan Wangji’s cool silence. “Fine, fine, I know I got the better end of the deal here. Who wouldn’t want to be the beautiful, powerful Hanguang-Jun, shining Jade of Gusu and the cultivation world’s most eligible bachelor —” 

“Wei Ying,” Lan Wangji says again, tensely.

“Okay, okay, I’ll stop teasing.” For now.

He rustles himself to his feet, tripping for a moment — Lan Wangji’s robes are tighter than his, and his limbs are longer, his feet bigger. He’s surprised to feel that Lan Wangji catches his elbow, propelling them both forward.

“This isn’t so bad, Lan Zhan,” he says as they start walking again. “It could even be fun. Think about it — when will this kind of thing ever happen to us again?” 

“No,” says Lan Wangji, and that’s all he says, but it shuts Wei Wuxian up, and they’re silent the rest of the way.

— 

It’s still early afternoon when they finally get back to the Cloud Recesses. Lan Wangji immediately drags him to the yashi before anyone can catch sight of them, Wei Wuxian whining in protest the whole time. The rest of the hunting party must not be back yet, still out looking for the creature; the Cloud Recesses are even more silent and austere than usual.

He waits around, bored and restless, while Lan Wangji tends to the head wound Wei Wuxian had managed to pick up before they’d been cursed. Wei Wuxian watches as Lan Wangji gingerly dabs at the blood with a wet cloth until it’s just a pink, shallow scratch; he watches him move around in his body for a few moments more, then finally has to look away. The whole thing is too strange and surreal, watching himself with Lan Wangji’s mannerisms and tics.

Lan Wangji’s pristine white robes have been muddied with dirt and blood, but Wei Wuxian isn’t sure offering to change them will go over well, given Lan Wangji’s stormy expression as he attempts to clean his face. 

Still, the headband is itchy and sticking to his forehead with sweat. How does Lan Zhan stand this all the time —

“No touching,” Lan Wangji says sharply, seeing Wei Wuxian’s intent — which, of course, means he has to touch it now. 

“Why not?” Wei Wuxian says, his lips creeping up in a mischievous grin. “I am Hanguang-Jun, after all.” He runs a thumb along the fine silk of the headband, smiling wider when Lan Wangji turns a dangerous shade of pink. “What’s so special about it, anyway—”

“Stop,” Lan Wangji says in a low voice, a vein in his forehead starting to pulse. Wei Wuxian concedes, laughing and throwing his hands up in surrender.

“Fine, fine. For you, dearest Lan Zhan, I’ll stop.”

“Stand still,” Lan Wangji orders, crossing to him, and Wei Wuxian gives a mock-serious nod and straightens his shoulders as tight as they’ll go, holding his head aloft and adopting Lan Zhan’s usual deadpan.

Wei Wuxian squirms in place as Lan Wangji considers him silently, his eyes trailing from head to toe. The metal of his ridiculous headpiece is digging painfully into his scalp, pinching the roots of his hair; he’s sweating like a pig under all these layers, and all the dried sweat and blood from earlier is uncomfortable; his ribs itch from the undershirt stuck to his body — 

“Stand still,” Lan Wangji says again, not harsh but stern, and Wei Wuxian stops fidgeting and starts sulking. “Temper your expression.”

Wei Wuxian’s lip had been edging toward an instinctive pout; he schools his expression, straightening his shoulders and fixing his features in a neutral, somewhat bored look. He hoods his eyes for extra effect.

Lan Wangji, with Wei Wuxian’s head, nods once in approval. “Good.”

“So, what — I just have to not move at all, do nothing, and look like a corpse, and people will believe it’s you?”

Lan Wangji gives him a look that Wei Wuxian thinks is supposed to be wry and doesn’t deign to respond.

“What about you?” Wei Wuxian counters. “Nobody is going to believe it’s me for a second if all you do is stand there, look imperious, and say Mn.”

Something fleets across Lan Wangji’s (Wei Wuxian’s?) face — embarrassment, maybe — before it passes just as quickly, and Lan Wangji returns to glaring at him.

Wei Wuxian feels a helpless grin steal over him again. He bounces forward into Lan Wangji’s space, the becoming-Hanguang-Jun lesson forgotten at the prospect of merciless teasing.

“What do you know about being shameless, Lan Zhan? Have you ever tried it?” 

Wei Wuxian is perhaps a little too thrilled to see a low flush start at the base of Lan Wangji’s neck. Lan Wangji’s gaze cuts away, purposefully avoiding eye contact as he practically simmers with discomfort.

Wei Wuxian leans closer, and it’s strange to be this close to his own face and features, to see them move independently in a manner that’s nothing like he would recognize of himself.

“It’s okay,” he hears himself saying, before he can stop himself. “I can teach you. I’m an expert on this topic.”

Lan Wangji tenses further, his gaze fastened to some apparently fascinating speck of dust on the floor. “No need.”

“Ah, Lan Zhan.” Wei Wuxian’s voice borders on a whine, which is both hilarious and surreal, hearing it in Lan Wangji’s low baritone. “Make this a little fun for me, will you? It’s the least you can do, seeing I’m stuck as the venerable Hanguang-Jun with all his boring, insufferable duties and rules for the foreseeable future.” 

Lan Wangji’s expression doesn’t change, but Wei Wuxian sees the bob of his throat as he swallows. 

“What would you…have me do,” he says quietly.

Wei Wuxian counts this as a small victory, and he feels a huge grin split his face. It feels different from smiling with his own — more wooden, less natural, like Lan Wangji’s facial muscles aren’t accustomed to the expression.

“Well, first off, you can drink as much as you want to now,” he says, and Lan Wangji starts to glare again. “No, really, I mean it! My body has the tolerance of a horse. Two horses, probably. You can tease Jiang Cheng as much as you want to — in fact, I’d encourage you to, to fully sell the part. Pranks are good, breaking rules is good.” He pauses. “What do you know about flirting?”

Lan Wangji full-body flinches like he’s been scalded. “Ridiculous,” he snaps.

“I’m just being thorough! Wei Wuxian is well-known among young cultivators as being a shameless flirt, and good at it,” Wei Wuxian insists, ignoring the way Lan Wangji’s starting to look like he swallowed something extremely sour. “You can practice on me, if you’d like. Friend to friend.”

Lan Wangji takes a step back, like he’s unconsciously trying to flee.

“See, that’s exactly what you won’t do,” Wei Wuxian says disapprovingly. “Lan Zhan, you’ve faced down vengeful spirits, fierce corpses, and a mythical, murderous turtle. What could possibly be so scary about this, eh? It’s just talking.”

“I…do not know how to,” Lan Wangji says, then looks furious at himself for the admission, his brows pulling together.

“Sure you do. I’ve been flirting with you for ages. Just copy what I’ve been doing.”

Lan Wangji’s head snaps up. He stares at Wei Wuxian with a slapped expression. “You…”

“Me…?” Wei Wuxian prompts.

The blush is crawling up steadily toward Lan Wangji’s jaw. “You…flirt. With me.”

Wei Wuxian arches his eyebrows. “…yes? You can’t mean that you haven’t noticed.” Subtlety is not one of his strong suits, as he’s so endlessly been informed.

Lan Wangji appears to visibly struggle with digesting this information. Finally, in a quieter voice, he says, “Why.”

“Because it’s fun,” Wei Wuxian says with a shrug. “You’re so easy to rile up. Your ears get all red; it’s cute.”

Lan Wangji's expression shifts — if Wei Wuxian didn't know better, he'd say he looks crestfallen. Abruptly, though, the expression shifts to a scowl, too quickly for Wei Wuxian to question anything else.

“Lan Zhan ah, if you keep doing that with my face, it’ll get stuck like that,” Wei Wuxian chides.

“This will not work,” Lan Wangji mutters, more to himself than Wei Wuxian. “Xiongzhang will take one look and know the truth.”

“You underestimate my acting abilities,” Wei Wuxian says, who thinks he’s quite good at pretending to be things he’s not, when there’s suddenly a knock at the door. Both of them jump.

“A-Xian,” shijie says at the door with a warm, dimpled smile, and Wei Wuxian says brightly, “Shijie!” before remembering that’s exactly what he’s not supposed to do. 

Shijie’s gaze flits away from Lan Wangji to him, her brow creasing in confusion.

“…Wei Ying’s shijie,” he scrambles to recover. “Wei Ying, your shijie is here.”

Shijie still looks puzzled, possibly at the prospect of Hanguang-Jun speaking more words to her than he collectively ever has, but she sets the pot of soup on the ground to salute him. “Lan er-gongzi.”

Wei Wuxian remembers himself; he salutes back, keeping his back stiff and his features as neutral as Lan Wangji would. “Jiang-guniang.”

“A-Xian, I thought I’d find you here,” shijie says, turning back to Lan Wangji, who’s starting to look like ants are crawling up his spine. “The hunting party returned and they asked after you. They haven’t located the creature yet, but everyone said you did well today.” 

“He did,” Wei Wuxian says, crossing his arms proudly, and Lan Wangji shoots him a Look.

“Ah…yes,” Lan Wangji says, and just the two words alone are enough to sound the alarm bells in Wei Wuxian’s head. He watches, with rising concern, as Lan Wangji attempts to make expressions with his face. “Yes, I performed…admirably. I am certain that...several maidens would be impressed.”

Wei Wuxian covers his face with one hand.

Shijie stares at him, faltering more uncertainly by the moment. “A-Xian, are you feeling well? You look….” She, understandably, can’t seem to find a word to describe exactly how Lan Wangji looks, as Wei Wuxian doubts anyone would.

“I’m fine, shijie,” Lan Wangji says, more animated than before, and Wei Wuxian peeks out from between the slats of his fingers, surprised. “You brought pork ribs and lotus root soup?”

Shijie visibly relaxes; Wei Wuxian frowns. How does Lan Wangji know his favorite soup?

“I couldn’t find lotus here in the Cloud Recesses,” shijie admits, stooping to pick it up, “but I made the next best thing. I even added extra spice for my Xian-Xian.” She reaches out to affectionately tweak his nose. Wei Wuxian watches as Lan Wangji physically struggles not to reel backward at the familiar touch.

“Thank…you,” he says, and Wei Wuxian has to bite his lip to keep from jumping in.

Usually, he and shijie would spend another several minutes talking and teasing, catching up, eating together. But Wei Wuxian is familiar with Lan Wangji’s tolerance for spice — shijie will know immediately that something is amiss if he starts to gag on her soup. 

“Jiang-guniang,” he says, quieting his voice in the way that Lan Wangji does, and Lan Wangji flares a look of disgruntled surprise in his direction. “Please forgive the imposition, but I need to discuss certain matters with Wei Ying in private.”

Shijie can hardly contain her surprise. She darts another glance back to her presumed brother, who is watching her with all of Lan Wangji’s characteristic, face-melting intensity. 

“I, ah—of course, Lan er-gongzi.” She looks at Lan Wangji again, confusion clear in her face, before she says, “I hope A-Xian will enjoy his soup, and that we’ll talk later.”

Lan Wangji nods once. “Yes. Of course.”

Shijie salutes Wei Wuxian one more time, and casts another searching glance at Lan Wangji, clearly trying to catch his eye to communicate something, but Lan Wangji keeps staring into his soup, his head down.

The moment shijie leaves, Wei Wuxian says with a gusty sigh, “Well, that could have gone better.”

Lan Wangji surprises him, then — he tentatively sniffs at the soup, then takes a sip.

“Hey!” Wei Wuxian darts forward to snatch the bowl from him. “That’s for me!”

Lan Wangji makes a slightly pained expression, then pauses to consider. Then he says, near-thoughtful, “Your tastebuds have evidently become numb to extreme spice, after years of regular destruction.”

“Thank you,” Wei Wuxian says with a sniff, then takes a sip for himself. He immediately chokes and sucks in a breath, Lan Wangji’s bland, virgin palate rebelling at the overwhelming burn of the spices, but he’s determined to enjoy this one good thing left to him, in these circumstances, so he continues to eat, tears streaming down his cheeks.

“Jiang-guniang,” Lan Wangji says after another moment. He stares at the doorway, looking uncertain. “She knew. That something was wrong.” 

“Ah, it’s fine. Shijie knows me better than anyone, so of course she would realize something is off,” Wei Wuxian tells him, slurping down the soup noisily in a way that would surely make any member of the GusuLan sect keel over in shame. “I don’t expect you to know exactly how to be me, after all.” 

Lan Wangji pauses, then after a quiet moment, begins to speak, with a lilting hesitancy. “You…have a furrow between your brows when you are focused, or cultivating.” 

“Hm?” Wei Wuxian pauses in his soup-slurping.

“Sometimes you stick your tongue out, too, when you concentrate,” Lan Wangji says, still in that soft, reflective voice. “When you laugh, you throw your head back; sometimes you clutch your own arms, or sides, when you cannot stop. You stroke your nose twice, when you are thoughtful or irritated. Your nose crinkles when you smile with all your teeth; you have a dimple on one side. You always push your hair out of your face, like you need to see things more clearly.”

Wei Wuxian stares at him, soup forgotten. That’s more words than Lan Wangji has said to him in…well, ever.

“You notice a lot of things, huh?” he says after a moment, recovering from his surprise. There’s a weird flush of warmth in his belly that’s surely from the spice of the soup. 

“Mn,” Lan Wangji says. Then, like a punctuation mark, “I do.”

—

An hour later, Wei Wuxian is napping, sprawled out on the steps of the jingshi to soak in some of the late afternoon sunlight, when he’s rudely awoken by someone hitting his knee.

He jolts into consciousness. “Aiyo!”

“Sit up straight,” Lan Wangji orders, and Wei Wuxian takes a few moments to blink, dizzy and disoriented, at his own angry face swimming before him. “If anyone were to see…”

“See what?” Wei Wuxian says petulantly, then looks down at himself. Lan Wangji’s body is draped over the steps, his white-clad legs akimbo and spread, one knee cocked up on a different step than the other, his head resting on one of his hands.

“You must meditate at least three times a day to maintain core and yang energy,” Lan Wangji instructs. “My body, it’s…”

“Built?” Wei Wuxian suggests, running an interested hand over the sharp, lean cut of Lan Wangji’s ribs, his hips. “I must say I’m impressed, Hanguang-Jun. No one would guess at all this muscle under all those stuffy, needless layers.”

“Stop at once,” Lan Wangji grits out, and Wei Wuxian bursts into a loud, delighted peal of laughter to picture the image that’s eliciting the horror mirrored back on his own face — the esteemed, pearl-white Hanguang-Jun, sprawled out in overly formal attire, still muddied and bloodied, feeling himself up in broad daylight. 

“I’m sorry, I’m sorry,” Wei Wuxian chuckles, clambering to his feet. “But learn to take a compliment, will you? You have nothing to be ashamed of. In fact, I —”

“Enough.” Lan Wangji is turned profile to him now, staring off with a fixed, steely expression, a muscle in his jaw working. His ears are red. Wei Wuxian’s never seen his own body blush before, obviously, so it interests him. “This is an unfortunate enough predicament without you…you…”

“Aren’t you a little curious?” Wei Wuxian teases, drawing closer. Lan Wangji takes a responding step backward. “It isn’t every day you get to wake up in a body that’s not your own. It’s okay to have questions.”

The second the words leave his mouth, Wei Wuxian has an unbidden image of Lan Wangji touching Wei Wuxian’s own body, running his hands over it the way he himself just had — undressing himself, staring in the mirror and — his mouth immediately dries out, heat buzzing through his head.

Lan Wangji’s lips are pinched with tension, his shoulders rigid at Wei Wuxian’s implications. His fists are so tight that his knuckles whiten.

“No,” he hisses, and that’s all he says.

“Okay, okay,” Wei Wuxian says, putting his hands up in concession. He’s admittedly a little unbalanced by the very thought that’s perhaps troubling Lan Wangji so much. “I promise I’ll behave. I won’t take advantage of you, Lan Zhan, I swear. I wouldn’t do that.”

His tone must be severe enough because Lan Wangji relaxes an increment, but not completely.

“But you do have a nice body,” he can’t resist adding, all in one breath, and Lan Wangji says, near-spluttering, “You —” then nothing else.

“Here,” Wei Wuxian says, “come here,” and turns Lan Wangji by the shoulder. “I haven’t gotten to see my own face up close yet.” He grabs Lan Wangji with one hand by the jaw as Lan Wangji startles backwards, and intensely peruses his own features as Lan Wangji struggles in his grip — but for once, he has the upper hand on physical strength and height, thanks to Lan Wangji’s stature.

“Hmm,” he says, examining each feature while Lan Wangji freezes in his grip, mute with what Wei Wuxian can only assume is fury. “All of my features are backwards than how I usually see them. Ah, you know, I don’t think I’m as handsome as people say I am. At least, not anywhere as handsome as Hanguang-Jun.”

“Hey!” calls out a harsh, familiar voice, and both of them go very still. “Lan Wangji, what the hell do you think you’re doing?!”

Realizing how the situation must appear to an outsider, Wei Wuxian lets go of Lan Wangji at once. They both turn.

“Jiang Ch — Jiang-zongzhu,” Wei Wuxian says hastily, with not even a scrap of Lan Wangji’s usual composure. He salutes.

“What the hell were you doing?” Jiang Cheng demands, stalking over to them and casting a frank once-over to Lan Wangji. “Wei Wuxian, is he bothering you?”

“Yes,” Lan Wangji says, honestly, and Wei Wuxian makes an affronted noise. “No. We were talking.”

“That looked very touchy for talking,” Jiang Cheng says, and crosses his arms with a suspicious scowl to Wei Wuxian. “I don’t care if you’re a precious Jade of Gusu, Hanguang-Jun, if you lay a hand on my brother—”

“That’s enough, Jiang Cheng. You look like a puffed-up grape when you make threats,” Wei Wuxian says, and really, he has fraternal reflex to blame more for that than anything, but Lan Wangji makes a hissing sound through his teeth and Jiang Cheng’s jaw drops open in comical shock.

“What — what did you just say to me??” he splutters, uncoiling his hand at once. Zidian crackles with a flash of electric purple. “Just what are you trying to start, Lan Wangji?”

“Wei Ying,” Lan Wangji says with Wei Wuxian’s mouth, and Jiang Cheng looks at him so fast his neck nearly cracks.

“What the hell is going on?” he shouts, and Wei Wuxian knows very well that firstly, Jiang Cheng is going to start whipping people, probably, until he gets a coherent answer, and secondly, it’s going to make a public scene.

“Jiang Cheng!” he says, at the same moment that Lan Wangji says, firmly, “Jiang Wanyin, control yourself.”

Jiang Cheng’s head whips back and forth between them like he’s following a particularly zippy and irritating fly.

“Don’t call me Jiang Cheng!” he blusters, pointing an accusing finger at Wei Wuxian. “Lan Wangji, where’s your sense of propriety?”

“Where’s yours?” Wei Wuxian returns. “Jiang Cheng, Jiang Wanyin — put Zidian away and let us explain, please?”

Jiang Cheng hesitates, clearly torn, before his confusion wins out, and then Zidian recoils, curling around his finger into its resting serpentine shape. “Talk. Now.”

“So, the night hunt,” Wei Wuxian begins, and Jiang Cheng turns to stare at him, visibly baffled to hear Lan Wangji speaking so informally — or at all, for that matter. “There was a…small setback. Lan Zhan and I, we separated from the group because we had a lead — don’t look at me like that, I would have brought you with us if I didn’t know you would react like this — and the creature lured us into a cave; things got very loud and very bright all of a sudden, and when we woke up, everything was dark and the creature had vanished, and —”

“I am in Wei Ying’s body, he is in mine,” Lan Wangji says, more succinctly than anything Wei Wuxian’s continued rambling would offer.

Jiang Cheng gapes at them for another moment before he turns to Wei Wuxian, wearing Lan Wangji’s face, and says, “You deserve this.”

“Hey!” Wei Wuxian protests. “Well, I mean. I’m not complaining too much. Look how cute he is, no?” He pinches Lan Wangji’s dirtied sleeve and then winks at Lan Wangji, who’s glowering at him and flushing to his roots. 

“Only you could be so shameless wearing the skin of Hanguang-Jun,” Jiang Cheng says through his teeth. “This is bad. Very bad. You do realize that the rest of the sect leaders are gathering here in three days’ time? If that display just now was the best you’ve got, they’ll immediately know something is wrong. The GusuLan sect will have your head for defiling their most precious disciple with your demonic tricks.”

“Hey,” Wei Wuxian says again, much more weakly than before, because no, he hadn’t considered that possibility, and yes, Jiang Cheng is absolutely right.

“Wei Ying didn’t do anything wrong,” Lan Wangji cuts in, to Wei Wuxian’s relief. “It was an honest mistake. I will see if the library can provide answers for how to switch back.”

Wei Wuxian groans at that and stretches. Lan Wangji’s body is much suppler than his, given all his rigorous training and the abundant golden core energy flowing through him. When he gets back to his own body, he won’t have that anymore.

Wei Wuxian viciously shoves the last thought down, and the sharp ache that accompanies it.

“You can go to the boring library,” Wei Wuxian tells Lan Wangji. “I was thinking of going to Cold Spring.”

“No,” Lan Wangji says, in such a frightful voice that it brings Wei Wuxian up short.

“What? I’m not trying to be inappropriate. You told me to meditate, and you’re right — Cold Spring is the best place to do it.”

“No,” Lan Wangji repeats, and Wei Wuxian sulks at him.

“Can you stop thinking about getting undressed for two seconds?” Jiang Cheng asks Wei Wuxian, exasperated. “You’re an embarrassment.” 

“I wasn’t! Thinking about that, I mean—” Was he? He certainly is now. Wei Wuxian is shocked to find his ears are hot. 

Hmm. Maybe not so shameless, after all.

Lan Wangji, without so much as a by-your-leave, turns and stalks off toward the library, his black-clad shoulders a stiff line and his arms clasped behind his back. 

“Hey, Lan Zhan!” Wei Wuxian calls after him, disappointed, then bites out, “Ow,” when Jiang Cheng elbows him hard in the ribs.

“What’s wrong with you? Can’t you leave him alone?” Jiang Cheng demands. “This situation is humiliating enough for him without your torturing him.”

“I’m not torturing him,” Wei Wuxian protests, wincing and rubbing the tender spot on his ribs.

Jiang Cheng huffs. “Imagine being trapped in the body of the person you hate the most. No wonder he can’t stand the sight of you, parading his body around and acting like that!”

Wei Wuxian stares after Lan Wangji’s receding form, a tightness lodging in his throat. He knows he’s irritating, usually deliberately so, but does Lan Wangji still really dislike him so much? Even after everything?

“—time to act like a fool about your giant crush on Lan Wangji,” Wei Wuxian tunes back in to Jiang Cheng saying. “Have a little decency, for my sake if not your own.”

“I don’t — I don’t have a —” Wei Wuxian stammers, unbalanced by this unexpected affront, and he grapples for words for the next few seconds while Jiang Cheng watches, his eyebrows creeping closer and closer to his hairline. Eventually, all Wei Wuxian can summon is, “Jiang Cheng, what are you saying?” 

Jiang Cheng rolls his eyes upward as though seeking answers from the heavens. “Crush, infatuation, whatever it is. Just leave him alone until we get this sorted out.”

“I don’t like him!” Wei Wuxian protests, still stuck on this heinous accusation. “I mean, I like him just fine, but a crush, I mean, he’s—he’s so boring, and stuffy, and mean.”

“You like mean,” Jiang Cheng points out.

Wei Wuxian has never felt so attacked in his short, painful life. 

“Believe me, I don’t pretend to understand,” Jiang Cheng says, with a properly nauseated expression. “But we’re wasting time. Let’s follow him to the library and look for answers.”

They walk together in uncharacteristic silence, and surely an odd sight they’d make to any Lan disciples walking by—the impervious, tall, reserved, dove-white Hanguang-Jun, still dirtied and bloodied from today’s night hunt, side by side with the scowling and colorful Sandu Shengshou.

Wei Wuxian can’t shake Jiang Cheng’s words, even though they’d clearly only been meant to nettle him. They shouldn’t — Jiang Cheng has historically said far, far worse.

Wei Wuxian had, admittedly, been somewhat obsessed with Lan Zhan in his early days at Cloud Recesses. Fine. But it was only because he was entertained and fascinated by Lan Wangji’s clear, unadorned hatred of him. As the weeks had gone on, it had turned into a fun challenge, or a particularly frustrating riddle, to try to get Lan Wangji to like him, to make him stammer and blush, to watch his gold eyes spark like molten metal when his temper flared. 

Wei Wuxian has long made a sport of being annoying, but so far, he’s charmed his way out of every instance where exasperation toed the line of ill regard. There hasn’t been anyone, as far as he’s known, who has genuinely disliked him in spite of his best efforts. Except for Lan Wangji. (Well, and Madam Yu, but she doesn’t count.) 

It had been funny, at first, and then a private thrill to attempt to charm him, and Lan Wangji certainly isn’t hard to look at. Wei Wuxian has always been unabashedly hedonistic, admiring beautiful things and beautiful people in all forms, and there is no finer specimen in the cultivation world than the jade-edged Hanguang-Jun. 

Who could blame him if he is a little infatuated, after all?

But Jiang Cheng is right. To Lan Wangji, Wei Wuxian knows he’s brash, loud, crass, intolerable to his very idea of existence. Over time, the more experiences they’d shared together, he’d thought that maybe…maybe he hadn’t imagined the way he’d caught Lan Wangji looking at him when he thought Wei Wuxian wasn’t paying attention. But likely, he realizes, it had been wishful thinking, because he wants Lan Wangji to like him. He really does.

He wants Lan Wangji to really like him.

“Are you listening to me, Wei Wuxian?” Jiang Cheng snaps, and Wei Wuxian comes back to himself, blinking. They’re in front of the Library Pavilion now, and Jiang Cheng is scowling at him.

“What?” he says, succinctly.

“I said, once we get in there, leave Lan Wangji alone,” Jiang Cheng says, and Wei Wuxian sighs and nods.

He will, he’ll be nice. He’ll be good. He’ll try.

Lan Wangji does not go to the Library Pavilion, as he said he would. Instead, once he gets there, he heads right back to the jingshi, the long way around, to clear his head. He’s far too scrambled at the moment to sit in the heavy, enfolding silence of the library, to focus his energy for hours on end on the neat lines of texts and scrolls.

For a moment, once he steps into the jingshi, Lan Wangji just breathes, closes his eyes, and tries to allow the familiar aromas of incense and sandalwood to calm his mind. 

Then Lan Wangji stares down at his hands — Wei Ying’s hands. He has always thought them beautiful in their own way, somewhat smaller and darker-skinned than his own, rough with calluses from sword-fighting and archery and climbing trees and—whatever else Wei Ying had done in Yunmeng. Nonetheless graceful, and nimble, and sure.

Wei Ying talks a lot — almost anyone, other than Lan Wangji, would say too much — but Lan Wangji is always listening, hoarding pieces of information like a crow with pieces of scrap metal. He’s hungry to know every detail of Wei Ying’s life, his passions, his interests, what makes him laugh, what makes him upset or sad. At first, his dedicated interest in this matter had confused and infuriated him, but he had long ago given up his resistance to liking Wei Ying, helplessly and adoringly. 

Now that he’s alone with Wei Ying’s body, his thoughts are deafening, too loud for his head. Far, far too often than he would ever allow himself to admit, he had imagined, dreamed about what Wei Ying would look like, with the layers all gone, but this — this is not what he envisioned. This is never something he would have asked for, or desired for either of them. It feels horrifically invasive, and shameful, and —

Lan Wangji locates the single, floor-length mirror in the room and for a moment, just stares, his breath catching. 

He can never let himself look at Wei Ying for too long, so he can never drink his fill of Wei Ying’s features the way that he’d like to— he stores flashes of Wei Ying’s expressions and features away, guards them jealously to turn over later in the most private corners of his thoughts. He isn’t sure what to do now that he’s allowed to....look, for as long as he wants to.

Lan Wangji sits, his legs crossed, and leans closer to the bronze glass.

Wei Ying is handsome, of course — unmistakably beautiful, no matter what self-deprecating, laughing remarks he throws away. The most beautiful person Lan Wangji has met in his life — as he’d known, unfortunately and immediately, from their first moonlit fight on the rooftops of Cloud Recesses. It had angered him, flustered him, and…

He raises a shaking hand to Wei Ying’s cheek, catches one brush of soft, warm skin before he yanks away as though he’s been burned.

No. 

He isn’t allowed this. It’s not the same as if — as if he himself were to touch Wei Ying, like this. Would he be allowed to? Would Wei Ying let him? 

Still, he can’t resist drawing one finger, feather-light, over the bow shape of Wei Ying’s lips, so often curled up in a coy or delighted smile. He tries to smile to replicate the expression, but it feels wrong, lifeless, hollow. He suddenly, fiercely misses Wei Ying in his own body; Lan Wangji is a trespasser here, taking up space somewhere where he doesn’t belong.

And…

He drops one hand to cup Wei Ying’s sternum, feeling the emptiness there like a dark void. Wei Ying’s golden core, surgically and cruelly hacked out — with a knife? With a scalpel, a hand? There's nothing left behind except a carved-out space that Lan Wangji can feel like a drumbeat.

He feels sick. He thinks, for one sure moment, that he’s going to be physically ill, when he hears a single knock and a clatter of feet at the door, and — it’s Wei Ying, awkward and clumsy in his too-big body, who stops and stares in confusion at the sight of Lan Wangji on the ground.

Lan Wangji jerks back from the mirror, his stomach still twisting.

Wei Ying keeps staring, and asks, “Lan Zhan, are you okay? I couldn’t find you in the library, so I thought that’d you…”

It takes a blink for Lan Wangji to realize there are tears in his eyes, and that’s why Wei Ying is looking at him with such perplexed concern. He stands abruptly, almost stumbling as Wei Ying’s feet get tangled together beneath him.

“Yes,” he says. “What do you need?”

Wei Ying is still staring at him, through Lan Wangji’s own features, with an unbearably soft expression, and Lan Wangji feels that sick, tilted lurch again like the ground dropping out under his feet. Is this what he looks like, when he looks at Wei Ying? Is it so obvious?

“Here, sit,” Wei Ying says, taking Lan Wangji by the wrists and leading him to sit on the bed. “Listen. Lan Zhan. I know this whole thing, with — with the soul-switch, it’s upsetting. And believe me, I know my body is the last one on earth you’d want to be inside of.” 

Lan Wangji chokes, then passes it off as a cough.

“I know I haven’t made this easy,” Wei Ying continues, looking so earnestly remorseful that Lan Wangji’s heart gives a pathetic little kick. “But I promise, it’s not forever. We’re going to find a way back, especially with Jiang Cheng helping us now.” He frowns, thinking seriously on something for a moment, before he adds, “I’m sorry it had to be me.”

Lan Wangji is a step behind, but doesn’t say anything, waiting for Wei Ying to clarify.

Wei Ying correctly interprets the silence and clarifies, “I’m sorry I was with you for the curse, when it happened. I’m sure you’d prefer to be stuck in this with anyone else, and I don’t blame you.” 

He scratches the back of his head, looking sort of forlorn and so unlike himself that Lan Wangji fights the bizarre urge to place a hand on his own shoulder. 

Still, he cannot allow Wei Ying to get this so wrong, as he does with so many other things between them.

“No,” he says, firm. 

“No?” Wei Ying echoes.

“You are wrong,” Lan Wangji says quietly. “Wei Ying is the only person that would make this tolerable.”

Wei Ying’s eyes widen, and then brighten, and then he smiles, an expression so unfamiliar on his own face and so very Wei Ying that Lan Wangji stares. 

“Well, good, because I feel the same way,” Wei Ying says, leaning one shoulder familiarly into Lan Wangji’s. Lan Wangji’s toes curl in his shoes. “Can you even imagine if I had swapped with Jiang Cheng? Or Jin Zixuan? I would do everyone a favor and throw myself off a cliff.” 

“Wei Ying,” Lan Wangji is horrified into saying.

“Kidding, kidding,” Wei Ying says, backtracking with a chuckle. “Aiya, so serious, Lan Zhan. I’m almost never serious, you know?”

“I do,” Lan Wangji mutters, and Wei Ying laughs openly and throws an elbow into his ribs. 

“Okay, okay. I know you’re going to be angry with me for this suggestion, but really, Lan Zhan, look at my clothes.” 

Lan Wangji does look. The usually-spotless white is faded with dust, streaked here and there with dried blood and mud. It’s a rare occurrence, maybe nonexistent, that anyone should see Hanguang-Jun in such a state, and of course, in any other situation he would change clothes the moment he returned from the hunt, but… 

He swallows with discomfort. 

“And yours,” Wei Ying says, tugging at his black lapel. “I know you have a strong sense of modesty, but something must be done.”

Wei Ying is right — of course he is. And yet Lan Wangji still feels a crimson flush starting at the base of his throat, spreading up like wildfire.

“I know you Lans are — ah, private folk,” Wei Ying says, his eyes tracking the vertical progress of the blush. “But bodies are just bodies. I promise I’ll be as respectful as possible.” 

Lan Wangji wants to tell him it’s fine, that he trusts him — that he’s right — but of course, he can’t say any of that. He doesn’t trust himself to say anything at all.

“How’s this — I can change clothes here, if you like,” Wei Ying suggests. “We’re already in the jingshi, and that way you can look at me, and I’ll keep my eyes on you.”

That does make Lan Wangji feel somewhat better. He relaxes and gives a slight nod. Wei Ying smiles in response.

“Thank heavens,” Wei Ying groans, rolling away from him and stretching his arms above his head. “I thought I was going to die if I stayed in these any longer. Okay, help me. I don’t know how to get any of this off.”

Lan Wangji’s pulse crashes in his throat, in his ears, but he rises without a word and helps Wei Ying with the outer two layers with practiced ease, folding each one neatly on the bed.

“Oh, this is strange,” Wei Ying says, with a faint laugh, “looking at my own face while you do this.”

Lan Wangji resolutely ignores the itchy heat in his ears and helps untangle the other layer until it’s just the inner robe left, and his pants. He’s never seen his own body from the outside, and of course doesn’t think much of it either way, but he does wonder what Wei Ying truly thinks of it — what it would look like to him.

“Do you want to take things from here?” Wei Ying asks, staring at him uncertainly. 

“Leave the pants on,” Lan Wangji says, and swallows hard. “I’ll get clean clothes for the rest.”

“Lan Zhan, I’m going to have to bathe at some point,” Wei Ying calls after him, as if Lan Wangji needs any reminder of that excruciating fact. “Hanguang-Jun is well-known for his fresh, aromatic musk. You can’t have him walking around looking and smelling like this.”

“Enough,” Lan Wangji says, hearing the laugh in Wei Ying’s voice and feeling ridiculously flustered.

“It’s okay, Lan Zhan. I understand,” Wei Ying says, more thoughtful than before. “Being in another man’s body repulses you, of course.”

That is certainly not the problem. Lan Wangji suddenly wonders, with a flash of dread, Is that how Wei Ying feels about it?

“But I swear, my body’s not that bad! Other than, ah, the lack of spiritual power. It’s probably not even that much different than yours.” 

Lan Wangji wishes he would just stop talking. He returns and drops the fresh robes at his feet, glaring up at Wei Ying — rather than glaring down, as is usual.

Wei Ying smiles at him, sunny and beatific. He pitches his voice low, gazing at him from underneath dark lashes. “Thank you, Wei Ying.”

Lan Wangji can’t help it — he scoffs. It’s not quite a laugh, but Wei Ying perks up regardless.

“Now you,” he says, then begins quickly and effortlessly stripping Lan Wangji before he can blink.

Lan Wangji makes an instinctive noise of protest and rears back, but Wei Ying frowns at him and says, “It’s only fair,” so Lan Wangji just stands there, numbly, dumbly, as Wei Ying uses Lan Wangji’s own hands, fingers, arms to divest him of his clothes.

“My body can just borrow some of your training robes while I clean my usual clothes, if that’s alright,” Wei Ying is chattering, the cadence of which sounds strange in Lan Wangji’s voice. “I’m sure you’ve got them stored away in the back of your closet somewhere.” 

Lan Wangji feels cool air brush against his chest as Wei Ying pushes off his red inner robe, and he closes his eyes. The heat is back, everywhere, making him feel flushed all over. He will not look. 

“Lan Zhan, it’s fine,” Wei Ying says, sounding amused. “I appreciate your chivalry, I really do, but I have nothing to hide.”

When Lan Wangji opens his eyes, Wei Ying is similarly bare before him. He maintains determined eye contact with Lan Wangji, as if to prove true on his word.

“See? Not so bad at all,” Wei Ying says, gentler now, and Lan Wangji looks away.

“We can bathe in Cold Spring later,” Lan Wangji tells the wall. “That way we can keep undergarments on.”

“Whatever makes you comfortable,” Wei Ying says, and then he pauses, and Lan Wangji jumps when he feels the tentative brush of fingers across his abdomen. On reflex, he catches Wei Ying’s hand to stop him, and then the two are caught as though in amber, staring at each other.

“Sorry,” Wei Ying says, swallowing. “It’s just, aha — it’s my body, and from the outside, I hadn’t seen…”

Lan Wangji can’t help it; he looks down, where his fingers are still wrapped around Wei Ying’s. A large, pink scar blooms below Wei Ying's navel, the skin raised and puckered, and it still looks somewhat new, as though it recently finished healing.

Lan Wangji stumbles at the sight of it, his head spinning with imagery of what it means, of what Wei Ying had endured to get it.

“Lan Zhan,” Wei Ying says, steadying him with large, cool hands. “Ahaha. I know I have a nice body, but fainting is a little dramatic, don’t you think?” 

Like a man possessed, Lan Wangji forgets his promise to himself: He drops his hand to the scar and traces two gentle fingers over the shape of it. As though his touch could absorb the pain, the memory of it into himself.

He hears Wei Ying’s sucked-in, choked breath as though from far away.

“I’m sorry,” Lan Wangji says, his hand jerking away as though burned. He closes his eyes, unable to look Wei Ying in the face. “I’m sorry.” 

“Hey, no apologizing,” Wei Ying says. His voice sounds fainter than before. “I told you it’s okay to be curious. It’s ugly, isn’t it?”

Lan Wangji chokes on his words again. He wants to say that no part of Wei Ying could ever be ugly, never, never — but he doesn’t, just breathes. He could drown in unspoken words, in the sea of everything he hasn’t said. 

“You know, Hanguang-Jun, you’re surprisingly sweet,” Wei Ying says, his eyes sliding over Lan Wangji’s face thoughtfully. “Such a gentleman, as they all say.”

Lan Wangji shoots him a half-hearted glare, certain he’s being teased again, but Wei Ying just smiles back at him, his expression open and bemused. 

“You’re always doing that, surprising me,” Wei Ying says, and then his smile falters into a serious line, and he stares at Lan Wangji, more intently than before, like he’s trying to parse something out from him.

Lan Wangji takes a step back, putting more space between them. Wei Ying’s expression shutters at once, and he picks up the clean inner robe from the floor.

“Only three layers, Lan Zhan? Won’t people think you’re a tease?” Wei Ying says, and Lan Wangji ignores him, just focuses on putting on his own clothes while trying to see as little of Wei Ying’s body as possible. Trying to burn the image of the scar from his mind.

“It’s been a long day,” Wei Ying continues once he’s fully dressed. He adjusts his forehead ribbon with a casualness that makes something in Lan Wangji lurch with both horror and something else that he can’t decipher. It might be longing, which he’s discovered takes infinitely painful forms. “I’d say it’s time for a drink, wouldn’t you, Lan Zhan?”

“No,” Lan Wangji replies at once, and he tries not to envision the horrors of a rowdy Wei Ying getting drunk in his body.

“Lan Zhaaaan,” Wei Ying whines, crowding closer to him and taking both of his wrists. He starts to lightly swing their hands from side to side. “Lan Wangji, Hanguang-Jun, Ji-xiong, Lan er-gege—”

“Stop that,” Lan Wangji says quietly. He deflects the warmth of Wei Ying’s teasing, probing gaze, and focuses on fixing one of his sleeves.

“Surely you won’t deny me this?” Wei Ying continues, wheedling and relentless. “I still have some Emperor’s Smile back in my room. Think of how traumatic today has been for both of us. Let me have a little happiness, yeah? There’s nothing else to do in the Cloud Recesses. I’ll stay right here in the jingshi with you; no one will see Hanguang-Jun getting drunk, I swear on the Heavens and Earth.”

Lan Wangji has quickly come to discover that he can’t resist Wei Ying a single thing, especially where his happiness is involved, and the revelation has been somewhat unfortunate. It does not bode well for him, given the force of Wei Ying’s will could rival that of a noonday sun’s.

He sighs, and looks up into Wei Ying’s pleading eyes, the gold there lighter and warmer than it’s surely ever been.

“Fine,” he says.

Wei Ying brightens even further, the wattage on his smile doubling. Lan Wangji can’t look at it directly, even on another’s face.

“Wow, wow,” Wei Ying says musingly, still grinning. “I really didn’t expect you to say yes! You’ve changed from the boy I met on the rooftop, Lan Zhan. I like the new and improved you.”

Lan Wangji tries to ignore the pleased warmth that gutters to life in him at these words, like a candle flaring up.

“Don’t move,” Wei Ying says, squeezing his wrists before letting them go. “I’ll be right back.”  

Lan Wangji tries to say, “No running,” but Wei Ying is out the door before the words have left his mouth. He sighs, and stares uncertainly after him. Although they had managed to keep the secret from Jiang Yanli, it’s only a matter of time before everyone else knows the truth, including his brother. The ruse is seemingly too impossible for both of them to keep up.

Lan Wangji closes his eyes, feeling weary to the bone. He sits on his bed, soaking in the quiet, the gentle rustle of the trees outside his window. Wei Ying will be back soon with alcohol, which Lan Wangji, at one point not so long ago, never would have permitted. Wei Ying will cozy up into his space, and touch him with casual, teasing hands, and Lan Wangji will burn, as he has for what feels like a lifetime.

Heavens help him, he thinks.

When Wei Ying returns, he finds Lan Wangji upside down, his heels against the jingshi’s wall and his arms shaking with strain beneath him.

Lan Wangji sees Wei Ying pause and set the two jars of Emperor’s Smile on the table, then he ducks his head upside down to grin at him. “Lan Zhan. What are you doing?”

It’s pretty self-evident what Lan Wangji is doing, so he doesn’t bother to answer.

“Ah, Lan Zhan, I think you’ll find my body lacks the upper strength of yours,” Wei Ying says with a chuckle, sitting cross-legged at the table and giving him a delighted look.

“...Mn,” Lan Wangji concedes, because it is true.

“Although my core strength can’t be beat. Ha!”

Lan Wangji does his best from his current position to scowl unappreciatively at him.

“Too soon for core jokes, I see. That is noted. Why are you doing handstands, Hanguang-Jun?”

“Focus,” Lan Wangji says through gritted teeth. He can feel all of the blood in his face pounding from the effort of keeping himself upright. “And restraint.”

“Neither of which I have,” Wei Ying points out. He tilts his head, his eyes gleaming with mischief. “Is there someone specific who has tested your focus and restraint, Hanguang-Jun?”

“Ridiculous,” Lan Wangji retorts on reflex, but it comes out sounding very wheezy and weak.

Wei Ying laughs at him, clutching his sides as he does so. Lan Wangji finally gives in, kicking off from one of his heels so that he’s upright again. Wei Ying politely applauds him.

“Maybe if you stay in my body longer, I can be as fit as you are,” Wei Ying teases. “You’re welcome to wear it out all you want, you know.”

Lan Wangji has no reply to that, so he sits down across from Wei Ying at the table in lieu of a response.

Wei Ying nudges one jar of the Emperor’s Smile at him across the table. “For you.”

Lan Wangji says nothing in reply, but nudges it back in a clear rebuttal.

“Fine. More for me, then.”

“Wei Ying,” Lan Wangji says, and Wei Ying pauses just as he leans his head back to take a swig. “Be careful.”

“I’m always careful,” he answers with a wink. He starts to earnestly gulp the liquor with such a fixed eagerness that for some reason Lan Wangji looks away, feeling hot and embarrassed. 

“I don’t understand why you react to this so strongly,” Wei Ying says after he finishes the first bottle, reaching over to grab the second. “I don’t even f—” His shoulders suddenly sag, his eyelids drooping. “Oh.”

“Wei Ying,” Lan Wangji says.

“Mmmmm. I’m — tired, Lan Zhan,” Wei Ying murmurs, sounding confused, and then his head lolls, and he’s out.

Lan Wangji stares in disbelief for another moment — never, in their entire relationship, has he witnessed Wei Ying rendered so obsolete by liquor — before he sighs, crossing to him to help him lay down. It will only be a matter of time before he wakes.

In the meantime, Lan Wangji practices the guqin. Without spiritual power, the notes ring quite hollow, and they’ll have no effect on Wei Ying either way, but his fingers are true to the melody, and it sounds pleasant regardless. After only a few minutes, his fingertips ache against the strings; Wei Ying has none of the calluses that he’s built over thousands of hours of practice, over the years.

Eventually, after about two joss sticks’ time, Wei Ying starts to stir, mumbling to himself and clutching his head. Lan Wangji rests his palms on the strings, then crosses back to join him.

Lan Wangji helps him into a sitting position, his hand lingering in the crook of his elbow. “How do you feel?”

“I feel…” Wei Ying pauses and frowns, as though searching hard for a word, before he settles on, “Very drunk.”

Lan Wangji huffs a quiet breath.

Wei Ying casts about for a moment, then latches on to Lan Wangji’s arm. “Lan Zhan, how can someone with your body and your constitution be such a lightweight? I don’t understand it.”

“Xiongzhang is the same way,” Lan Wangji replies, trying to conceal the amusement in his voice. “You were warned.”

“I was,” Wei Ying says. “I feel like it’s — like it’s hitting more by the second, oh.”

“Mn,” Lan Wangji says, and suppresses the fond tilt of his mouth.

“Are you laughing at me?” Wei Ying peers at him suspiciously through red-tinged eyes. “That’s your laughing, Wei-Ying-is-so-stupid ‘mn.’”

“A little,” Lan Wangji admits, and Wei Ying’s eyes widen in surprise, and then delight.

“Fine, I deserve it,” he says, and as though encouraged by the way Lan Wangji is looking at him, he scoots closer to Lan Wangji’s side so they’re shoulder to shoulder. “Laugh at me, Hanguang-Jun, I want to hear you laugh.”

Lan Wangji presses his lips together against another small smile. He does not laugh, because he never does, but Wei Ying’s face grows softer at the expression, his eyes widening.

Lan Wangji lets go of his arm, and sits across from him, cross-legged at the table, and sets out a cup for himself, and one with water for Wei Ying.

Wei Ying hazily watches him for a moment before he speaks.

“Tell me, ah — Lan Zhan,” he slurs, then blinks at him. “Have you ever liked someone?”

Lan Wangji hesitates in his tea-pouring, probably for too long. Then he resumes and gives one nod.

“Oh,” Wei Ying says. “Wow! I can only imagine the type of person to capture Hanguang-Jun’s attention.” He laughs, but the sound is strangely brittle.

For a conflicted moment, Lan Wangji wages an inner battle — fighting not to ask the question he knows will only torment him, but that he’s dying to know the answer to.

After another few beats of silence, he gives in. Asks, quietly, “And you?”

Wei Ying stares at him with a glassy, slightly unfocused expression. He nods then, unusually serious.

A crosswind of emotion tears through Lan Wangji, jealousy and despair vying for dominance. Of course Wei Ying has liked people — Lan Wangji already knew this. Wei Ying flirts and charms and loves with a crushing force; it’s only the natural assumption that Wei Ying has fallen for someone, maybe multiple people. But to hear it confirmed — to know there’s another, even at some point in the past — settles like an ulcer in Lan Wangji’s stomach.

Wei Ying blinks at him sleepily, then props his chin on his hand, almost missing it. He sways a bit in place. “Can you tell me about her, Lan Zhan? I’m curious.”

Lan Wangji keeps his eyes down. Surely, the truth is glaringly obvious, just by looking at his face.

“Brave,” he answers, after another moment. “Clever. Brilliant. Warm. Caring. Funny. Selfless. Beautiful.” 

The paltry handful of words seems almost unfair in their lack, so woefully inadequate. Lan Wangji doesn’t spill out the words that he could say: that before Wei Ying, his life had felt like an unending, gray rain, and Wei Ying had been like the first ray of sun fracturing through the gloom, incandescent and revelatory and impossible to resist.

Wei Ying is staring at him with a strange expression. Lan Wangji can’t quite decipher it.

“Such a romantic after all, Lan Zhan ah,” he says softly after another minute. “She sounds like quite the person indeed, to have won the heart of Hanguang-Jun.”

Lan Wangji glares at him in exasperation, but Wei Ying is looking at the floor now, his expression closed off, uncommonly quiet. Lan Wangji was expecting more teasing, so the reticent reaction surprises him.

Wei Ying’s eyes flutter closed, and he sways again.

“Wei Ying,” Lan Wangji says, standing to cross over to him. “You should sleep.”

“Don’t want to,” he mumbles, leaning into Lan Wangji’s touch. “Wanna do something with you.”

“Do something,” Lan Wangji echoes, a question for clarification.

“Something fun.” Wei Ying lurches to his feet, planting a hand on the table to steady himself even as Lan Wangji keeps a firm grip on his opposite arm. “Let’s break rules. It’s so boring here.”

“Wei Ying promised to stay in the jingshi,” Lan Wangji reminds him, with absolutely zero faith in this tactic.

Wei Ying frowns, his brows scrunching together and his lip pushing out slightly. “Never did.”

“Your memory is poor,” says Lan Wangji.

“I’m tired of being dirty, Lan Zhan,” Wei Ying complains, and holds out his arm demonstratively. “Look how dirty.” A despondent look crosses his face. “I’m in Hanguang-Jun’s body and I’ve made him so dirty.”

“Wei Ying,” Lan Wangji says, not entirely sure if they’re having a conversation with a double meaning. “It is fine.”

Wei Ying groans, then shrugs out of one of Lan Wangji’s outer layers. It crumples to the floor. His brow is dewed with sweat. “Let’s go to Cold Spring, Lan Zhan. I’m so hot and dirty.”

“No Cold Spring,” Lan Wangji says firmly. He cannot even fathom the repercussions of someone finding his intoxicated body trawling through Cloud Recesses. 

This had, indeed, been a spectacularly awful idea.

“I’ll be so quiet,” Wei Ying whispers, clinging onto both of Lan Wangji’s arms. Lan Wangji wilts a little. “I’ll be so good, Lan Zhan, I promise, please.”

“No,” Lan Wangji repeats, with wavering certainty. 

Wei Ying, even drunk, smells a victory and presses his advantage. “It can’t be comfortable for you either, having all that muck and dirt and sweat from earlier on your skin. If anyone sees us, you can talk for us, okay? I’ll be my best Hanguang-Jun and be totally quiet.”

Lan Wangji sighs. He doesn’t believe Wei Ying is fundamentally capable of being quiet in any circumstance. However, Cold Spring does sound appealing at the moment, even if just to clear his addled mind. And it will perhaps help Wei Ying calm down from whatever state he’s working himself toward.

“Do not leave my side,” he warns, and Wei Ying beams and affectionately pets his cheek.

“Good boy, Lan Zhan, you’re so good to me,” Wei Ying mumbles, listing sideways a bit, and Lan Wangji once again has to question his own soundness of mind. 

He leads Wei Ying toward the entrance of the jingshi, and then they’re out into the fresh evening air, cooler than inside but still warm enough to warrant a trip to the springs. Wei Ying sighs contentedly, then slips his hand into Lan Wangji’s and squeezes. Lan Wangji almost physically starts, heat blazing in his cheeks at the casual gesture.

Keeping an iron grip on his hand, Wei Ying leans his body into Lan Wangji’s, a warm press at his side. “Nice night.”

“...Mn,” Lan Wangji says, sensing that his input is desired.

“Look at the moon,” Wei Ying says in a low, singing voice, tipping his chin upward to stare with an awed expression. “So strong and devoted and handsome.”

Lan Wangji looks at him strangely, then replies, for lack of something better to say, “Yes.”

Wei Ying closes his eyes and hiccups, still gripping onto him as they walk. “I’m gonna regret this tomorrow, aren’t I, Lan Zhan? Am I acting foolish?”

“No,” Lan Wangji says kindly.

“Yes I am,” Wei Ying sighs. “I’m an embarrassment to the GusuLan sect.”

“No,” Lan Wangji repeats, with more force.

“Hm. If you say so,” Wei Ying says, complacent again. “It’s no wonder you don’t drink, Lan Zhan. I’ll never pass judgment on you again, I promise. This is very tragic for you.”

Lan Wangji is content to let Wei Ying babble as they make their way along the wooded path to Cold Spring. He keeps a keen eye out for anyone who may be out walking and see them, but Wei Ying’s senses are duller than his own, with his lack of spiritual power. The moonlight illuminates their way along the steep path, at least, the surrounding trees tipped in silver like a colorless painting.

When they reach Cold Spring, Lan Wangji helps Wei Ying pick his way down the slippery rocks — and once they reach the water, Lan Wangji hesitates. Wei Ying doesn’t; he lets go of Lan Wangji and begins peeling off the rest of his layers, his expression slightly vacant but still set with concentration.

Wei Ying glances over to him, finally seeming to notice that Lan Wangji has frozen in place. “You can take my clothes off. I don’t care if you see me.”

I do, Lan Wangji wants to say, unsure how to proceed.

Wei Ying sheds his last layer, leaving Lan Wangji’s pale chest bare, nearly luminescent under the bright cast of the moon. He rolls his shoulders and his neck, then hooks his thumbs in Lan Wangji’s waistband —

Lan Wangji’s hand shoots out to stop him.

“What—?” Wei Ying frowns down in confusion at it, then says, “Oh, right. Why are you still dressed?”

Lan Wangji swallows, then squeezes his eyes shut when Wei Ying starts to undress him, his hands moving with quicker certainty than he would expect from his current state of inebriation.

“You’re so strange, Hanguang-Jun,” Wei Ying murmurs, and Lan Wangji feels the brush of night air against his exposed chest. “But I still like you.”

Wei Ying’s hands move to his waistband with intention, and again, Lan Wangji stops him, keeping his eyes closed. He can feel the hot throb of his pulse through every limb in his body, and he is suddenly very desperate to be in cold water, away from Wei Ying’s closeness and heat.

“What’s wrong with this?” Wei Ying asks in a low voice. The glassy, hollow look in his eyes gives away his drunkenness, but he sounds very much not so, and Lan Wangji swallows hard. “Are you really so disgusted by my body that you won’t look at me or touch me, Lan Zhan?”

Lan Wangji turns his face away, not possessing a single response to that. To deny it as emphatically as he feels would no doubt give him right away.

“Okay,” Wei Ying says, taking a step back. The moment he does, Lan Wangji aches for him closer. “Let’s swim.”

“Stay above water,” Lan Wangji tells him, suddenly alarmed, and Wei Ying waves him off with a hand.

“I’ve been swimming my whole life,” he says, dipping a toe in the water and recoiling from the temperature at once. “Could swim in my sleep.”

Wei Ying wades in waist-deep, visibly shivering, and Lan Wangji watches him from behind, again feeling strangely out-of-body — seeing his own half-naked form moving about the water, independently of himself.

After another moment of hesitation, Lan Wangji follows after Wei Ying, the chill lancing straight through him to the bone. Wei Ying’s body is unused to the conditions of Cold Spring, especially without a core to mediate the effects, so he shakes at the cold, shakes so hard that Wei Ying turns and notices.

“I think it’s warmer by you,” he says, drifting over with a mischievous smile, and Lan Wangji tries to take a stumbling step back but nearly hits a sharp rock with the heel of his foot. Steam curls up from both of their bodies, and for a long time, they just stare at each other, perhaps both absorbing the sheer oddness of their situation.

Lan Wangji does feel better in the water — more focused, less aroused and flustered. The chill drives out any distracting sensation; the pain of coldness is the only thing his mind can focus on. He had come here often when Wei Ying first arrived at the Cloud Recesses for these same results, meditating and reciting the Lan sect rules until he could no longer hear Wei Ying’s shimmering laughter, see his eyes or his smile or the curve of his narrow waist.

“Lan Zhan,” Wei Ying says, much closer now, and Lan Wangji’s eyes flare open. Wei Ying stands before him, taller, more muscular, paler, light-eyed, but the same person regardless, looking at him.

“I feel sober,” Wei Ying says, still slurring his words.

“You are not,” Lan Wangji informs him.

“The cold, though, it — it’s cleared my head a little,” he says, then frowns at him. “Lan Zhan, you look blue.”

“I’m f-fine,” Lan Wangji says, surprised and disgruntled to feel his teeth chattering.

Cold fingers find his chin and gently tilt his head up, and Lan Wangji steels his nerve and meets Wei Ying’s gaze without looking away. 

In the endless reading of his youth, Lan Wangji had read reports and stories in the library’s archives of Tao masters bursting suddenly into flame, withering up into ash within moments, seemingly with no explanation aside from some mysterious, esoteric form of spiritual ascendance. He had always scoffed with disbelief at the outlandishness of the stories. 

Now, he thinks he understands how it would feel.

Wei Ying’s eyes flicker across his face, as though intently searching for something, and after a moment, he smiles.

“I can still see you,” he says. “Even in my own face. Your eyes are the same.”

Lan Wangji shakes harder, not entirely from the cold. He starts to feel dizzy again. He should put a stop to whatever strange alchemy is unfolding between them — not like this, not when they don’t have their bodies and Wei Ying is too drunk to know left from right. Not like this.

“Can you see me too?” Wei Ying asks. 

His hand finds Lan Wangji’s chest, palm laying flat over his racing heart; it’s the only point of warmth in his entire body. Wei Ying reaches for Lan Wangji’s hand, now almost numb of feeling, and places it over his own chest, over the heart beating in Lan Wangji’s body. His own pulse also thunders there, much quicker than normal.

Lan Wangji tries to breathe.

Wei Ying looks down at himself then, as though drinking in the sight of Lan Wangji’s body, of their joined hands, before he murmurs, “All of this, and what do you do with it, Lan Zhan? Keep it selfishly stored away?”

“Stop,” Lan Wangji whispers, all the force and heat to the command gone. He isn’t sure what he’s asking anymore, or what he wants in this moment.

Wei Ying playfully skims a thumb over his nipple, stiff with the cold, and Lan Wangji returns to himself with the bolt of desire that cracks through him, weakening his knees. He pulls away at once, breathing raggedly. He wants desperately to touch himself, to quell the ache between his legs and make it disappear, but he can’t, not when —

Wei Ying blinks at him a few times, as though confused. He licks his lips and takes a step back of his own. Then, as if nothing had happened, he sets about washing his limbs in a methodical manner, scrubbing off the dirt and sweat off Lan Wangji’s body with an empty expression.

Still drunk, Lan Wangji reminds himself as he stares, his heart still galloping madly. Wei Ying won’t remember any of this, come tomorrow. 

He woodenly follows Wei Ying’s example, sluicing icy water over his arms and chest and face. He tries to ignore the gnarled knot of scar tissue in the center of Wei Ying’s abdomen, the sun-shaped brand seared into his pectoral, the roping burn scars from Zidian snaking along his sides and ribs. A physical topography of self-sacrifice — permanent reminders of Wei Ying’s opinion of himself when weighed against others’ needs. 

Lan Wangji wonders if one day, he can return the favor for Wei Ying with his own body.

“Let’s go back,” Wei Ying announces, abruptly moving toward the shore, and Lan Wangji blinks after him.

Wei Ying stumbles as he shrugs into Lan Wangji’s clothes, but is otherwise quiet and composed as Lan Wangji dresses alongside him. His old clothes feel grimy on his newly clean skin.

Wei Ying takes Lan Wangji’s arm again in a dutiful manner, as though Lan Wangji is the one who needs assistance, and pulls him up the wooded path, their shoes squelching beneath them.

For a long moment, there’s silence between them before Wei Ying speaks again.

“You know what, Lan Zhan,” Wei Ying says, drooping heavily into his side. “I think liking someone is the worst thing that can ever happen to a person.”

This conversation again. Lan Wangji experiences that same acidic sensation as he did before, eating away at his insides. To have to listen to this seems like a unique form of karmic punishment.

“It feels good, but it hurts,” Wei Ying whispers, staring off with a faraway expression, eyes hazy. “It feels like being sad, the ache of it, then it feels all warm and mushy when you see them, too. And it feels like...even the hurt is worth it, to know they exist. Do you know what I mean?”

Lan Wangji does. Oh, he does.

“No,” he says coldly, hoping to put a fast end to this discussion.

“Don’t ever like someone,” Wei Ying says mournfully. “I think I would rather get beaten up than feel this way even one second longer.”

Lan Wangji wants to ask just who it is that’s reduced the dauntless, shameless Wei Wuxian to such a state, but he doesn’t dare, for fear that once he has a name, he might track the person down and do something he regrets.

“Oh, it’s Zewu-Jun,” Wei Ying says, which snaps Lan Wangji right back to the situation at hand.

It is, indeed, his xiongzhang, moving toward them quickly and silently in the cover of the night, his multi-pronged headpiece glinting as it catches different shafts of moonlight through the trees. His hands are clasped behind his back, and his eyes are fastened to Wei Ying — to Lan Wangji’s form.

“Zewu-Jun,” Lan Wangji says respectfully, trying to salute while also keeping Wei Ying upright.

“Zewu-Jun,” Wei Ying repeats, clumsily doing the same. Lan Wangji closes his eyes and tries not to sigh through his nose.

Lan Xichen takes one look at Wei Ying and his nostrils flare. He turns to stare accusingly at Lan Wangji — with exasperation, not quite angry but his patience clearly tested. 

“Alcohol?” he says, lips pursed. “I assume this is your doing, Wei-gongzi?”

“Wei Ying did nothing,” Lan Wangji says in an immediate instinct to protect Wei Ying’s reputation, only to realize how stilted and formal the comment sounds coming from Wei Ying’s own mouth.

Lan Xichen stares at him, then back to Wei Ying, who’s still lilting suspiciously to one side.

“I...found him like this, in the jingshi,” Lan Wangji says. “I thought I would take him for a walk.”

“This behavior is not like Wangji at all,” Lan Xichen murmurs, staring at Wei Ying through his eyebrows with worry. “I fear something must have happened to deeply upset him.”

Lan Wangji stays silent; his brother’s concern touches him and discomforts him in equal measure.

“Wei-gongzi is...returning from Cold Spring?” Lan Xichen guesses, taking in the two of them still soaking wet. 

“Yes,” Lan Wangji says, trying to speak as Wei Ying would. “I thought it might — clear Lan Zhan’s head.”

Lan Xichen sighs. “That was thoughtful of you,” he says. 

“Mn,” Lan Wangji says, then catches himself and adds, “Yes.”

Lan Xichen takes a deep breath again, transferring his gaze from his brother to the real Lan Wangji before him. He hesitates, as though carefully picking his words, before he speaks.

“Wei-gongzi,” he says. “I trust you will be mindful of Wangji’s...feelings, in the future. I do not want to see him this way again.”

Lan Wangji feels heat itching in his throat. He has never tried to hide his feelings for Wei Ying from his brother, but to know he would speak to Wei Ying about it in such a way is mortifying.

Wei Ying, of course, chooses that moment to speak up.

“Zewu-Jun,” he says with a wet hiccup. He locks one hand onto Lan Wangji’s elbow. “Zewu-Jun, I like your Hanguang-Jun so much. I think I might keep him.”

Hearing this from his brother, Lan Xichen’s expression of perplexed concern returns at once.

“Wei-gongzi, please take Wangji discreetly to the jingshi,” Lan Xichen says. “And please ensure that no one else sees him like this.”

Lan Wangji nods, relieved to see the end of this horrible conversation. “Of course, Zewu-Jun. Thank you.”

“I think that went well,” Wei Ying muses, far before they’re out of earshot, and Lan Wangji walks faster, almost dragging Wei Ying behind him in his haste.

“Lan Zhan,” Wei Ying whines at him as Lan Wangji pulls him into the jingshi at last. “Don’t be angry with me, please.”

“Not angry,” Lan Wangji replies, meaning it.

“Are you sure? It seems like you’re angry at me. Then again, it always seems like you’re angry at me. You’ve never really liked me much, have you?”

“Wei Ying,” Lan Wangji says, both surprised and pained by the question. He has been informed by others, countless times, of his own ambivalence, that his cold exterior is like an impenetrable fortress, but to know Wei Ying thinks his regard for him so low sends a sharp, shooting pain through his chest. He’s upset with himself, incapable as he is of saying and doing as he means.

“Lan Zhan,” Wei Ying murmurs, seeming to sense his sudden inward retreat. He cups one of Lan Wangji’s cheeks, turning his face so they’re closer. “Don’t listen to me when I’m like this, I just say anything. I don’t know what I’m saying. Come to bed with me.”

Lan Wangji heaves in a breath, his instincts screaming at him to recoil, to shy away from this directness, but he swallows it down. How often has he gotten in his own way, when it comes to what he truly wants?

Still, he hesitates.

Then:

“Okay,” he hears himself say, and Wei Ying’s smile lights up the room.
