At last, Wei Wuxian thinks, he’s gotten Lan Zhan in bed with him — although, of course, it’s not quite in the context he wants. And it’s a distinctly less sexy context than his alcoholic alter-ego has been fantasizing about.

Lan Wangji is as stiff as a board next to him, his spine rigid and his eyes fixed to the ceiling. His hands are clenched to his chest in a facsimile of the Lan sleeping position, and he’s breathing shallowly through his flared nostrils.

There’s also the unignorable fact that he’s in Wei Wuxian’s own body, which is still too strange to reckon with.

“Lan Zhan,” Wei Wuxian murmurs, still sluggish with the alcohol. It makes his tongue thick in his mouth. “Calm down. I won’t do anything to you. I just wanted someone to lay down with me, okay?”

Lan Wangji looks like he wants to squirm but remains still, a pretty red flush climbing up his neck. Wei Wuxian reaches out a hand, splays his fingers across his chest, where he can feel Lan Wangji’s heartbeat rabbiting frantically against his palm.

“Lan Zhan,” he teases, curling in even closer. “Are you nervous?”

He watches Lan Wangji’s rigid profile, the way his throat gives a bob and dry click as he swallows. His breathing sounds quicker than before.

Right, right, Wei Wuxian remembers, somewhat woozy. Lan Zhan and his thing with touching people. He’s not sure they’ve ever been so close for so long; he can feel the solid warmth of Lan Wangji radiating into him.

The alcohol fogs everything in his brain, everything sensible and rational and responsible — he leans forward and presses his nose to the side of Lan Wangji’s neck, burying his face in the warm hollow between neck and shoulder. Lan Wangji jerks beneath him, his breath hitching.

For the first time that Wei Wuxian can recall, Lan Wangji doesn’t smell like his crisp, familiar sandalwood. He smells…earthy, sort of smoky, like the heat from a bonfire. Also sort of cold, from the spring. Is that his own scent?

“Is this fine?” Wei Wuxian mumbles, closing his eyes. “Please don’t get up and go. I don’t want to be alone.” 

There’s a beat of silence, and then Lan Wangji says, low, “I will not leave.” 

Wei Wuxian briefly smiles, wriggling in closer. When he’s sleepy, he latches on to everything in immediate vicinity and clings like his life depends on it — liquor, it would seem, has much the same effect. 

Poor Lan Zhan, he thinks as he drifts in and out of consciousness, fading between murky layers of blacks and grays. Forced into his body, forced into closeness with him. He’ll make it up to him one day. He will. He will, he’ll take him back to Yunmeng and buy him something nice, maybe a meal, take him out in a rowboat on the lakes when the day is sunny, put a lotus in his hair… 

The next thing he knows, Wei Wuxian is jerking awake into darkness on a stifled scream, his thin inner robe plastered to his skin with cold sweat, his pulse beating a fast, thready staccato into all his limbs. He’s thrashing, fighting, resentment spindling all around him in black-red coils, seeping into his body, his empty core, sucking everything out of him until there’s nothing but desiccated flesh—

The resentment crowds greedily around the cavity of his empty core; like a rotten tooth torn out from the root, blood filling the space behind. 

Do you want revenge, Wei Wuxian? Stay. 

You can have revenge. 

Stay with us.

“— Wei Ying,” he hears a frantic voice say, close to his ear, and yes, sometimes Lan Zhan had spoken to him there; had reprimanded him, scorned him, spat on him, told him how reviled he was, told him he deserved to die alone, and he knows that, he knows — 

I’m sorry, Lan Zhan, I’m sorry, please, please, please —

Stay, Wei Wuxian.

Stay.

“Wei Ying!” Lan Wangji repeats, more sharply than before, and it takes hearing it in Wei Wuxian’s own voice to realize he’s not in the Burial Mounds, not among corpses and seething resentful energy and the screams of the dead. He’s in a bed and a body that aren’t his own, his unfamiliar chest heaving for breath, and Lan Wangji’s fingers are encircled around both of his wrists, where he can feel his heartbeat sickly pounding.

“What —” he tries to say, heaves for air.

“A nightmare,” Lan Wangji says, simply, but the two words are so soft and concerned that it’s strangely grounding.

“I’m s-sorry,” he says, his teeth chattering. He’s so deeply, achingly cold, down to the marrow of his bones, and he’s shivering violently, great shudders racking his frame. 

He’s not there, Wei Wuxian tells himself. Just this again. Just another memory. His head still feels strangely woolly with the leftover alcohol, leaving a cottony taste in his mouth.

“Tea,” Lan Wangji says quietly, and goes to move, but Wei Wuxian grips onto his wrist so hard he feels the bones creak.

“Don’t,” he whispers, not entirely sure what he’s asking for—don’t pity me, please, not you? Don’t be kind to me, when I deserve it least? Don’t leave? He thinks it may be all of them at once.

Lan Wangji hesitates, his intense gaze scrutinizing, before he gives one nod and settles back into bed, then continues to stare at him. It’s odd seeing that appraising expression in his own eyes; with a sudden, fierce ache, Wei Wuxian misses the cool steadiness of Lan Wangji’s golden gaze, how warm the hues can be when they take him in.

Wei Wuxian can feel Lan Wangji’s core pulsating with energy, activated to the perceived danger. It shakes through him with a strength that has for some time been unfamiliar to him. He takes a deep breath, into his belly, and reigns it in with effort.

He can feel his brow still dripping with sweat. Lan Wangji reaches out with a sleeve and dabs it away.

“I’m sorry to wake you,” Wei Wuxian whispers, recoiling from the gentleness of the touch. All the moisture in his mouth is gone.

“No need,” Lan Wangji replies, just as quiet. “What can I do?”

Wei Wuxian drops his head into his hands. “Just…stop looking at me like that. Please.” His skin crawls at the prospect of being pitied, of being seen.

“Mn. No more looking,” Lan Wangji says, in such a serious, considerate voice that Wei Wuxian gives a sniffled, helpless laugh. 

“Lan Zhan,” he says, before he can stop himself. “I miss seeing you in your body. I miss your face.” Lan Zhan had always felt…big, solid, safe. Wei Wuxian had felt protected near him, no matter what. That, he doesn’t say.

Lan Wangji says nothing, but Wei Wuxian thinks he hears him inhale, sharp and quiet.

“Lan Zhan,” he says again, his voice hushed. “You’re a good person, you know that?”

Again, Lan Wangji says nothing.

“I’m sorry I tease you so much,” Wei Wuxian continues. “It’s just that I…” Like you so much I can’t stop myself. That, he also doesn’t say. He’d never dare. Even thinking it tears through him, brazen. 

“Stop apologizing,” Lan Wangji says, firm and terse. “Between us, there’s no need.”

“Okay,” Wei Wuxian says, and exhales shakily.

“Wei Ying." Lan Wangji hesitates again, gauging Wei Wuxian’s expression. “You dreamt of the Burial Mounds?”

This time, Wei Wuxian doesn’t answer, unsure that he’s able to. He’s suddenly terrified to think what his unconscious self had spoken, with Lan Wangji’s mouth. 

“It’s not important,” Wei Wuxian says, and Lan Wangji makes an impatient noise.

“This happens often?” he presses.

Wei Wuxian doesn’t say anything to that. He’s certain that his silence confirms it, as well as the fact that he starts shivering violently again. 

“Lay down,” Lan Wangji says abruptly, and after a moment of hesitation, Wei Wuxian does as he’s told, too tired to make any weak quips or innuendos about Lan Wangji bossing him around in bed.

He’s shocked to feel Lan Wangji turn him by the shoulders, his back to Lan Wangji’s front, despite Lan Wangji’s currently smaller frame.

When he opens his eyes, Lan Wangji is staring at him with an expression that Wei Wuxian doesn’t know how to name, but it makes a strange hunger cavern out inside of him. The candlelight flickers with the breeze from the open windows, and in the low, warm glow, Lan Wangji’s eyes burn like embers. He’s so beautiful that Wei Wuxian hears himself take a hitched, unsteady breath.

“Ah,” he says, feeling stupid. “Right.”

Wei Wuxian unbuckles his belt so that his top layers loosen, and with some grimaced struggling, he shrugs his injured shoulder out of his clothes. The scrapes and puncture wounds are marked almost behind the upper bridge of his shoulder, so he has to twist his head to examine it. Clots of dry blood are caked and crusted all along his skin, but it doesn’t look too serious.

Lan Wangji extends one uncertain hand with the cloth, and then hesitates.

“May I…” he starts, then swallows. His ears are pink, Wei Wuxian notices with weary fondness.

He had spent most of his youth in Yunmeng tearing around half-clothed with a gaggle of boys his age, so to see the Lans get so flustered over a bit of exposed skin is still a funny novelty to him.

“No,” Wei Wuxian answers. “I’m tougher than I look, Lan Zhan. I won’t break so easily.”

“I know,” Lan Wangji murmurs, and this, for some reason, is what makes a zing of heat circuit through Wei Wuxian.

He suddenly realizes that he’s on edge, but not in a tense way, more in the sense that — he’s hyper-aware of Lan Wangji’s every movement, his every breath. Lan Wangji steps away.

A warm bath, after a few days without one and the day he’s had, sounds absolutely heavenly. He shrugs his robe back on and thanks Lan Zhan for his help, and Lan Wangji nods and steps away, giving him some privacy as he goes to prepare.

When he does bathe, Wei Wuxian is careful not to get his fresh bandages wet, lowering himself with a soft moan into the warm water. Chunks of dirt and dust slough off his skin like ashes, and for a long time, he just sits with his eyes closed, almost nodding off, before he attempts, poorly, to wash his hair, and then experiences an idiotic moment where he wishes Lan Zhan would do it for him. He would be so gentle and methodical about it, and Wei Wuxian suppresses a quiet ache when the image comes to mind, unbidden.

He swallows it down, banishes it into a tarry pit where he has buried these errant thoughts with a growing regularity.

Lan Wangji had hung a clean white inner robe on the side of the privacy screen, and Wei Wuxian slips into it gratefully, shivering in place for a moment, before he pads over into the next room, where he can hear Lan Wangji practicing the guqin.

Lan Wangji glances up at his entry, and then he does something that Wei Wuxian has never, in the entirety of their acquaintance, witnessed — he messes up, a discordant note pinging from the strings. It’s so startling in contrast with the gentle melody of the piece that Wei Wuxian almost flinches.

Lan Wangji drops his gaze back to the guqin, laying his palms over the strings. “I have spare robes you can borrow while your others are cleaned.”

“Okay,” Wei Wuxian says, rubbing his big toe against his bare heel.

Lan Wangji excuses himself to bathe then, leaving Wei Wuxian to get dressed and nap for a while until he’s done. The borrowed robes smell like Lan Zhan, crisp sandalwood and some other aroma he can’t quite name. He feels clean and fresh and he finally smells good, and in this honey-warm state he floats in and out of a light sleep, and thinks that Lan Zhan’s bed might be one of the most comfortable he’s ever slept in.

It makes him look, unfairly, even more like a deity than he did when blood-flecked and mud-soaked.

Wei Wuxian shakes himself awake, not wanting to be rude, but Lan Wangji softly says, “Wei Ying, sleep.” 

He’s almost tempted to, but Wei Wuxian actually, very much does want to hang out with Lan Zhan, in their time together. Between battles, sect drama, and family spats, it feels like they never have time like this — just to be with each other, the way friends should be.

“Not tired,” Wei Wuxian says, which is so obviously a lie that Lan Wangji’s eyes narrow a little, but Wei Wuxian stubbornly moves to the table across the room, where a pot of steaming tea is already prepared. The tea of Gusu is too acrid, too medicinal for Wei Wuxian's tastes, but Lan Zhan likes it, and so Wei Wuxian resolves to make himself like it as well.

Then Wei Wuxian kind of just props his chin on his hand and stares while Lan Wangji does things, like holding his white sleeve so it doesn't trail across the table, like pouring two hot streams of tea into their cups. Lan Wangji nods.

Wei Wuxian gapes at him, speechless.

The words are a blow Wei Wuxian wasn’t expecting at all. Tears spring to his eyes immediately at the force of it.

Lan Wangji gasps against his mouth, and Wei Wuxian remembers himself, yanks his body back.

He drops one hand to place a palm over Lan Wangji’s heart, where he can feel a pulse hammering frantically against his skin.

“Mn,” he says into Wei Wuxian’s shoulder — then, as if he’s afraid he’ll be misunderstood, he adds, more clearly, “Yes.”

In fact, his poor heart is currently swooning like a lovestruck loon, but he doesn’t want to push it, not when he’s unsure the depth of his feelings will be matched — not when he’s already gotten this.

“Mn,” Lan Wangji mumbles, and Wei Wuxian laughs and presses a kiss to his temple. I love him, he thinks, and the immediacy, the fondness of the thought are as flattening as they are natural, like he’s drawing a breath, like his heart is beating.

“Lan Zhan, you're so cute like this,” he says instead, cupping both of Lan Wangji’s cheeks so he can properly look at him, so he can drink his fill of Lan Wangji's mouth swollen and wine-red, the gold in his eyes eclipsed by black, his forehead ribbon askew. The unfair, improbable beauty of him. He had missed this face just in the past couple of days more than he ever imagined he could.

“I missed seeing you,” Lan Wangji says, unconsciously echoing his thoughts as he lays his hands on top of Wei Wuxian’s. He adds, almost inaudible, “I always miss Wei Ying.”

Wei Wuxian exhales for a long beat, trying to breathe around those words. “All of this endearing honesty, er-gege. Where did it come from all of a sudden?”

“I couldn’t say it before,” Lan Wangji whispers, his eyes on the floor, and the words feel confessional.

“Why not?” Wei Wuxian asks, just as quiet. 

“I was afraid,” Lan Wangji says. He adds, impossibly softer, “I couldn’t bear if you hated me.”

The thought is so inimical to his very core that Wei Wuxian physically starts. “Hate you? Lan Zhan, I could never. Hate you, psh — I’ve always thought you were the smartest person I’ve ever met but I guess I was wrong. That is so dumb. I would beat up any version of me who hated you. I want to beat you up a little bit for even thinking that.”

Lan Wangji makes a noise into his hair, and Wei Wuxian realizes with a belated thrill that it might have been a half-laugh.

“Hate you,” Wei Wuxian mutters, still mortally offended. He kisses the spot between Lan Wangji’s eyebrows as though he’s been doing it every day of his life. His nose brushes against the ribbon. “Ridiculous.”

Then he pulls at Lan Wangji’s robes, topples them both backwards until he’s flat on his back and Lan Zhan is hovering over him, his long hair swinging down and tickling his face. Wei Wuxian tugs his clothes again, insistent, until Lan Wangji understands and carefully lowers his body weight against his, a warm and steady press into the ground. He’s careful to bear down more on the left side, mindful of the twinge in Wei Wuxian’s shoulder.

Wei Wuxian makes a contented humming noise, wrapping both his arms around Lan Wangji’s shoulders so that he’s hugging him, tight enough that their heartbeats clash against each other’s chests. He kisses the underside of his chin while Lan Wangji just gazes down at him, half-fond, half-mystified, like he’s not quite sure what to do with him.

“You feel good like this,” Wei Wuxian explains, and kisses him again. Lan Wangji leans into it eagerly, his thigh shifting between both of Wei Wuxian’s, and both of them pull back to take staggered breaths at the sensation.

“Maybe…” Lan Wangji says slowly, and Wei Wuxian watches with delight as his ears start to glow pink. “This...may be more comfortable on a bed.”

Wei Wuxian’s mouth falls open in mock-astonishment even as an excited heat bursts through him. “Lan Wangji. So shameless! Is Lan er-gongzi really offering to throw me over his shoulder and bed me? By the heavens, my virtue has never been so besmirched. Such a wicked proposition to defile my temperance and restraint—”

“Wei Ying,” Lan Wangji says, sounding pained. “I only meant that…” He struggles for a minute, and Wei Wuxian almost feels bad for him. Almost. 

“I’m joking, of course,” Wei Wuxian says with a grin. He loops his arms around Lan Wangji’s neck. “Fine, have your way. Ravish me, Hanguang-Jun.” 

Lan Wangji is unconscious. 

Surely that’s the only rational explanation for how any of this can be happening — he'd knocked himself out fighting the creature earlier, and his subconscious is being extraordinarily cruel in its realism, even crueler than usual, or —

“Lan Zhan,” Wei Ying says, a hot thrum against his ear. “I can hear you overthinking. Stop it.”

They’re still standing in the middle of the jingshi, where Lan Wangji had frozen the second they’d pulled themselves up. Wei Ying’s arms drape over his shoulders, and he’s gazing up at him with his cheeks flushed and his lips slightly swollen and his eyes uncannily bright.

Lan Wangji blinks down at him, and tries to recalibrate.

“Was the ravishing bit too much?” Wei Ying asks, looking genuinely worried for Lan Wangji’s health. “I was only kidding, really. Sometimes my mouth just starts and I can’t stop it for anything.”

“I am fine,” Lan Wangji says, returning to the earthly plane.

“We don’t even have to do anything,” Wei Ying says, taking both of his hands and looking up at him with such sweet earnestness that Lan Wangji’s heart constricts in his chest. “I just want to be close to you. We can just lay down and do nothing, I don’t care. Whatever you want.”

What Lan Wangji wants could fill this room tenfold. His fear is that he wants too much.

“I want…” Lan Wangji tries to say, but his mouth has always failed him, when it comes to Wei Ying. He makes a frustrated sound, then finishes, or perhaps supplicates, “Wei Ying.”

That will have to suffice; it’s not technically incorrect.

“You have me,” Wei Ying says, easy as anything, and Lan Wangji buries his face in Wei Ying’s shoulder at that, even as Wei Ying huffs a quiet sound of surprise.

“Ah, poor Lan Zhan,” he says softly, petting his hair, petting his back. “You’re far too good.”

“Stop,” Lan Wangji says, and Wei Ying laughs, not a trace of mockery in it.

“Come, come,” Wei Ying says, and Lan Wangji lets himself be guided toward the bed, where Wei Ying lets go of his hands and perches on the edge of the mattress to gaze up at him through his lashes, coquettish.

Wei Ying’s mouth drops open, blood rushing to his face. Then he buries his face in his palms and says several mushed, unintelligible things there. Lan Wangji waits patiently.

Had it been too much to say out loud? It’s only true. Lan Wangji feels a great sense of unburdening — the weight of those unspoken truths had crowded his throat until he couldn’t breathe, and now, Wei Ying will know it all. As he deserves to.

“Lan Zhan.” Wei Ying is staring at him, a strange glow in his face. “Come here.”

Lan Wangji does.

Wei Ying scoots to the edge of the bed so that his knees fall apart, and he takes Lan Wangji’s hands again and tugs him so that he’s standing between his open legs. He only has two of Lan Wangji’s lighter robes on, cinched at the waist by a simple cloth belt, and he gently guides one of Lan Wangji’s hands to his hip. It’s a tentative question, and an invitation.

Lan Wangji takes a steadying breath, heart in his throat, and pulls at the belt so the robes loosen, slackening so they spill off of Wei Ying’s shoulders and collarbones. Wei Ying’s eyes are closed, his eyelashes a sooty sweep against his cheekbones. As though he’s waiting for something with bated breath.
